channel.title: Nature - Digg
channel.description: Nature on Digg: the best articles, videos, tweets, and original content that the web is talking about right now

item.title: The Crash Of The $8.5 Billion Global Flower Trade
item.description: As people everywhere cancel events and big cut-flower orders, the ripples reach into Dutch auction halls and Kenyan rose fields.

item.title: Ten Years After Deepwater Horizon, Worries Remain
item.description: Efforts to clean up the lingering effects of the oil spill are well underway, but secrecy and deregulation have returned to the Gulf, raising the specter of a repeat.

item.title: Colorado: Images of the Centennial State
item.description: A few glimpses of Colorado's landscape and some of the animals and people calling it home.
item.kicker: HIGH PLAINS TO THE ROCKY MOUNTAINS

item.title: Here's A Rare Glimpse At A Snow Leopard Shrieking Out Into The Void
item.description: The White Lion Foundation released an extraordinary, rare video of a snow leopard making a shriek caught on camera in the mountains of northern Pakistan.
item.kicker: MORE A SCREAM THAN A ROAR

item.title: Coronavirus Is Reducing CO2. Why That's Worrisome
item.description: A growing number of estimates say global carbon dioxide emissions could fall 5% in 2020. That would be the largest annual drop on record. But climate researchers say there is little reason for celebration.
item.kicker: CAN WE PLEASE CATCH A BREAK? ANYWHERE?

item.title: Watch This American Woodcock And Its Babies Do Their Trademark Funky Walk
item.description: The American Woodcock's remarkably bouncy walk helps it stir up worms in the dirt and it's a terrific wonder to behold — especially when its younglings are getting the hang of the motion.

item.title: What Would Have Happened To Wilson After 'Cast Away'?
item.description: An oceanographer, a marine biologist, a ship captain and the former CEO of FedEx weigh in.

item.title: Why Scientists Are Still Puzzled About The Great Unconformity In The Grand Canyon
item.description: Kallie Moore explains the mystery behind why there's a discrepancy between old rocks, formed billions of years ago, mixed with relatively young Cambrian sedimentary rock in the Grand Canyon and other places.

item.title: Inside The Ship That Stands Watch Over The Melting Arctic
item.description: You can tell the Norwegian research vessel Johan Hjort is made for the Arctic because it holds a tanning bed inside.

item.title: Guy Creates Waves On Frozen Lake By Driving A Four-Wheeler Across It
item.description: How the car didn't just drop straight into the lake, we do not understand.

item.title: Melting Ice Reveals A 'Lost' Viking-Era Pass In Norway's Mountains
item.description: Artifacts show people used the route for 1,000 years — then abandoned it, possibly amid a plague.

item.title: The Green Sludge That Could Transform Our Diets
item.description: Microalgae is rich in protein, amino acids, fatty acids and vitamins. Should we all be eating it?

item.title: Why Is 'Cottagecore' Booming?
item.description: The visual and lifestyle movement is designed to fetishize the wholesome purity of the outdoors.

item.title: A Construction Mistake In Rome That Created A Lake And United A Neighborhood
item.description: With no local government able to take control of the situation, an accidental lake became the unexpected catalyst of a community struggle for new ecological and urban imaginations.

item.title: Massive Wild Animals Wander Russian Streets In These Surreal Composites By Vadim Solovyov
item.description: Seeing a raccoon washing its paws in the rivers of Saint Petersburg or an octopus tumbling out of a city bus would be a startling sight for most city dwellers.

item.title: Here's The Weird Thing That Causes The Smell of Spring
item.description: You know the scent. Now meet the source.
item.kicker: WISH WE DIDN'T KNOW THIS NOW

item.title: Buried Alive In The Backcountry
item.description: Jenny Karns found herself upside down in a streambed, completely encased in snow and unable to move.
item.kicker: 'I REALIZED THAT I MIGHT NOT MAKE IT'

item.title: How Much Coronavirus Lockdowns Have Reduced Pollution In Major Cities, Visualized
item.description: The concentration of nitrogen dioxide has dropped substantially in cities around the world since the implementation of lockdown measures to stop the spread of the coronavirus.

item.title: Climate Change Won't Stop For The Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The next several months could bring hurricanes, floods and fire, on top of the pandemic currently raging through the country. How do you shelter in place during an evacuation?

item.title: How To Make A City Livable During Lockdown
item.description: From wider sidewalks to better balconies: tips from a long-time urbanist.

item.title: Well, Uh, Here's A Sea Gull Swallowing A Rabbit Whole
item.description: The great black-backed gull is the largest member of the gull family — and also apparently the most metal.

item.title: The Problem With Shrimp
item.description: Shrimp farming releases huge quantities of greenhouse gases, in addition to supporting abusive labor practices.

item.title: Coronavirus Closure Returns Yosemite To The Animals
item.description: The deer, bobcats, coyotes and bears no longer have to deal with the hordes of camera-toting tourist vying to capture nature. They now roam unfettered.
item.kicker: WE ARE THE — ACTUALLY, THE VIRUS IS THE VIRUS

item.title: The Mysterious Demise Of Freshwater Mussels
item.description: Mass mussel casualties, like those in Ohio's Big Darby Creek, are relatively new, and they are now happening worldwide.

item.title: The World's Smartphones Are Filled With Gold. That's A Problem
item.description: Small amounts of gold used in electronics quickly add up to environmental and humanitarian disasters.

item.title: The Pandemic Is Not A Natural Disaster
item.description: The coronavirus isn't just a public-health crisis. It's an ecological one.

item.title: Watch A Swamp Rabbit From Missouri Caught On Camera Swimming For The First Time
item.description: Watch these little-known creatures swimming in the swamps on Missouri.

item.title: Guy Scooped Up A Jar Of Pond Water And Left It On His Window Sill — What Happened Next Was Extraordinary
item.description: As an experiment, a YouTuber gathered a jar of muddy water and weed out of a local pond and placed it in his window. Here's what happened after the first week.

item.title: Man Has Hilarious Reaction To Giant 'Donald Trump Bird' Landing On His Car
item.description: A cattle egret was spotted standing on top of an unsuspecting Florida man's car, prompting him to make a spot-on observation.

item.title: A Year-Long Expedition Spotlights Night Life In The Arctic Winter
item.description: In a ship deliberately embedded in an ice floe, scientists are studying the base of the food web.

item.title: Are Plants Listening To Us? It Depends Who You Ask
item.description: A controversial 1970s book claimed that plants can hear. It turns out its authors might not have been entirely wrong

item.title: A Photographer Captured Breathtaking Images Of A 'Horizontal Rainbow' Over A Lake In Washington
item.description: Amateur photographer Cessna Kutz took two photos of the "horizontal rainbow" from her porch located on Lake Sammamish in Washington.

item.title: The Power Of Parks In A Pandemic
item.description: For city residents, equitable access to local green space is more than a coronavirus-era amenity. It's critical for physical, emotional and mental health.

item.title: Grow Your Own Food Using Plant Cuttings With This Ingenious Garden Hack
item.description: Here's five foods you can grow yourself using plant cuttings.

item.title: Bird Rehabber Teaches European Starling To Speak Words, And It's Pretty Wild
item.description: European starlings are astonishingly good at mimicking sounds. This intrepid wildlife rehabber taught it to say words related to its introduction to North America.

item.title: Closing The Parks Is Ineffective Pandemic Theater
item.description: Public green spaces are good for the immune system and the mind — and they can be rationed to allow for social distancing.

item.title: Here's A 150-Foot Long Silly String-Like Creature Scientists Discovered Near Australia
item.description: Researchers from the Schmidt Ocean Institute captured footage of a 150-foot long siphonophore off the western coast of Australia. Their R/V Falkor, a oceanographic research vessel, was exploring deep sea canyons, when it discovered the unusually large underwater creature.

item.title: The Way Starfish Walk Is Absolutely Mesmerizing
item.description: This striking video of a starfish walking along on the surface of an aquarium wall demonstrates how the animal moves using hundreds of tube feet.

item.title: Oblivious Guy Doesn't Notice Rhino Ambling Towards Him, Nearly Gets Squashed
item.description: The pros of living next to a national park? Easy access to nature, a chance to see wildlife up close, etc. The cons? When that wildlife wanders out of the park's front gate and nearly runs you over.

item.title: Well, At Least The Pandas Are Having A Nice Time
item.description: For the first time in more than a decade, two giant pandas named Ying Ying and Le Le, who reside at Ocean Park in Hong Kong, have mated naturally.

item.title: Scientists Unearth An Ancient Lost Forest 'Entombed' Off Alabama's Coast
item.description: These underwater cypress trees are 60,000 years old, and may help pioneer new drug treatments.

item.title: The Pandemic Is Turning The Natural World Upside Down
item.description: Widespread social-distancing measures have produced some jarring effects across land, air and sea.

item.title: This Twitter Thread Of Animals That Look Like Pokémon Might Be The Most Delightful Thing You See Today
item.description: Rebecca Helm, a biology professor at the University of North Carolina Asheville who specializes in jellyfish, put together an eye-popping Twitter thread of real world animals that she deemed "should be Pokemon."

item.title: This Mysterious Animal Looks Uncomfortably Like Venom Come To Life
item.description: It's most likely the bootlace worm, but we prefer to call it by its other name: the sentient alien Symbiote.

item.title: Rising Tides, Troubled Waters: The Future Of Our Ocean
item.description: The ocean is undergoing unprecedented changes. What does it mean for marine life, the planet and us?

item.title: Oceans Can Be Restored To Former Glory Within 30 Years, Say Scientists
item.description: Major review reports recovery of marine life, but a redoubling of efforts is still needed.

item.title: Here's An Intense, Territorial Fight Between Two Tigers Caught On Camera
item.description: Two full-grown tigers were caught on camera in central India fighting over territory according to a post by Indian Forest Service (IFS) officer Parveen Kaswan.
item.kicker: YOU GOTTA LISTEN TO THE ROAR

item.title: Photographer Traces The Flight Patterns Of Thousands Of Starlings In Mesmerizing, Soothing Video
item.description: We've seen videos that captured the murmuration of birds before, but never something as beautiful like this.

item.title: How Do Predators Learn To Avoid The Colors And Patterns Of Poisonous Prey?
item.description: Using video games, scientists show it has to do with the environment and network of prey available.

item.title: Extremely Helpful Bear Fixes Fallen Safety Cone
item.description: Wildlife photographer Michael Mauro captured a bear in Denali National Park making a considerate adjustment to a traffic cone.
